As for the intermediate stopover conditions, express buses can have one location each in the departure and arrival terminal areas and one location in other areas. There is no restriction on intermediate stops for intercity buses, and there is no need for intermediate stops for express and intercity buses.

There are also differences in fare pricing, but it would be too long to talk about this, so I will skip it.

And the most important thing is that many people do not know, but even if it is an intercity bus company, it can own an express route license, and even if it is an express bus company, it can own an intercity route license, and depending on the situation, intercity and expressway conversion is also possible. Top Answer:
이/가'는 주격조사, '은/는'은 보조사입니다. 기본적인 차이는 '이/가'는 격조사이기 때문에 이것이 붙는 것만으로 앞의 체언과 함께 주어를 이룹니다. 하지만 '은/는'은 보조사이기 때문에 주어, 목적어, 부사어, 서술어 등 거의 모든 성분에 사용이 가능합니다. 

​

또 다른 차이는 '이/가'는 알려지지 않은 새로운 정보와 결합하지만 '은/는'은 이미 언급되거나 알려진 정보와 결합합니다. 

​

옛날에 한 할아버지(가) 살았어

할아버지(는) 새끼 염소 한마리(가) 있었어

그 새끼 염소(는) 매우 귀여웠어

새끼 염소(는) 새로난 뿔(이) 아주 작고 귀여웠어

​

그래서 '이/가'와 결합한 정보는 '미지 정보(알지 못하는 정보)', '은/는'과 결합한 정보는 '기지 정보(이미 알고 있는 정보)'라고 합니다.
Top Answer (English):
I/GA' is a nominative particle and 'Eun/Eun' is an auxiliary. The basic difference is that 'i/ga' is a case particle, so just adding it forms a subject together with the previous noun. However, because 'eun/eun' is an auxiliary verb, it can be used in almost all ingredients, including subjects, objects, adverbs, and predicates.

​

Another difference is that 'this/is' combines with new, unknown information, while 'is/is' combines with information that has already been mentioned or known.

​

Once upon a time there lived a grandfather

My grandfather had a baby goat.

That baby goat was very cute

The baby goat's new horns were very small and cute.

​

So, information combined with 'is/ga' is called 'unknown information (information that is not known)', and information combined with 'is/is' is called 'known information (information that is already known)'.

At one time, when the solar calendar was adopted in 1895, there was a debate between the Western solar calendar and the lunar calendar, and after Japanese colonial rule and liberation, the solar calendar was designated as a national guide. Question: 더치커피 콜드브루 같은말?
Question (English): Same thing as Dutch coffee cold brew?
Top Answer:
더치커피와 콜드브루는 비슷한 커피 음료지만 약간의 차이가 있습니다.

​

더치커피는 일본식으로 추출하는 방식을 말하며, 커피를 물 대신에 냉수로 천천히 추출하는 방법입니다. 이 과정에서 시간이 오래 걸리고, 커피의 향과 풍미를 더욱 강조할 수 있습니다. 더치커피는 일반적으로 유리 병이나 커피 메이커를 사용하여 만들어집니다.

​

반면에 콜드브루는 커피를 찬 물에 장시간 절충하여 추출하는 방식을 말합니다. 일반적으로 커피 가루와 물을 12~24시간 정도 함께 냉장고에 절여두고 추출하는 방법입니다. 콜드브루는 부드럽고 산미가 적은 커피 음료로 알려져 있습니다.

​

따라서, 더치커피와 콜드브루는 추출 방식과 시간, 맛과 향이 약간 다르기 때문에 약간의 차이가 있습니다. 그러나 일반적으로 두 용어는 혼용되어 사용되기도 합니다.
Top Answer (English):
Dutch coffee and cold brew are similar coffee drinks, but there are some differences.

​

Dutch coffee refers to a Japanese-style brewing method in which coffee is slowly brewed with cold water instead of water. This process takes a long time and can further emphasize the aroma and flavor of the coffee. Dutch coffee is usually made using a glass jar or coffee maker.

​

On the other hand, cold brew refers to a method of extracting coffee by steeping it in cold water for a long period of time. Typically, coffee powder and water are steeped together in the refrigerator for 12 to 24 hours and then extracted. Cold brew is known as a mild, low-acid coffee drink.

​

Therefore, there are slight differences between Dutch coffee and cold brew as the extraction method, time, taste, and aroma are slightly different. However, the two terms are generally used interchangeably.
